lexUnit.name: fidget.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: make small movements through nervousness or impatience.

sentence.text: Men fidgeted nervously at the tables .
I saw Dacourt fidget nervously at his words .
She will lunch with selected guests in the new council offices , and an hour beforehand they are all turned out in their best suits and dresses fidgeting in anticipation .
TOM Courtenay fidgets in the chair , runs his fingers through hair grown long for his new stage role and chooses his words carefully before answering any question .
Instead she fidgeted in her seat , unable to relax , as the Mirror 's royal photographer Kent Gavin and I looked on .
The wedding between the two young gipsies was a moving ceremony , although Christian 's lengthy sermon had everyone fidgeting on the hard bench seats before it was ended .
The small audience had begun to fidget on their rickety folded chairs .

Usually worn by those smug bastards who fidget relentlessly on planes and insist on getting up and walking round the whole time , demonstratively taking photos out of windows and asking for guided tours of the cockpit .
Rachel fidgets round the room like it 's a hotel we got to leave by ten .
Edward began to fidget up and down the room .
I fidgeted angrily and the fellow licked his lips .
Alex fidgeted impatiently as Miles was brought forth on a stretcher , ignoring the welfare of the Base Coordinator completely .
` There is so much Isabel does not like , " she said , a note of real scorn in her voice that threw Dorothea into confusion , and she fidgeted , avoiding Kathleen 's eye .
Children fidgeted and chattered : mothers clutched babies in their arms and hauled toddlers on to their laps , making more room on the floor for people to sit .
As soon as lunch was over , Mr Evans was fidgeting to get back to the shop .
Mr Major fidgeted , and took an ever-so sneaky glance at his watch at 4:00pm to find to his dismay that only 30 minutes of the one hour , 53 minute-long drone had passed .
